30.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
Simon Barr from Realtree is shooting large

35.text:
black birds. First, how important is it that
your shot gun fits you? We find out on a simulated

46.text:
There are as many reasons for missing a bird
as there are for hitting one, but today we

53.text:
William Powell gunmakers has chosen a deep
flowing drive on the Hexton estate in Bedfordshire

58.text:
to show off their range of side by sides and
over and unders. It is a free try before you

64.text:
We are hosting an event today, because it
is a great opportunity for visitors to come

68.text:
along and try and use our guns. A gun is a
big investment to people. You would not buy

73.text:
a car without test driving it first, but plenty
of people buy guns for £10,000 without trying

81.text:
On hand are some of this traditional gunmaker's
gunroom staff to ensure these very smart guns

86.text:
fit you like a glove. Who knows how many shotgun
owners are out there with ill-fitting 12 bores.

92.text:
Imagine if Beckham wore boots two sizes too
big for him - he wouldn't be a shooting God

97.text: and neither will you be if you're not comfortable.

100.text:
People might come into the gun room, they
would pick up a gun. I have just got one of

103.text:
the Powells here. They close it up in the
gun room. It is all empty and they would close

108.text:
it up and just mount it. And it is very easy
for you in that false situation when you are

113.text:
not shooting, under pressure to mount a gun
and you make your body fit the gun. And you

119.text:
fundamentally do lots of different things
to make you fit the gun. For instance with

123.text:
this gun, if I put my hand just a bit further
along the stock, along the barrel sorry and

128.text:
all I do when I mount this gun, if I mount
it up, you can clearly see now that my head

133.text:
is very far back on the stock. The stock looks
massively long for me. Not change the gun

137.text:
at all. Place my hand down on the action,
mount the same gun and suddenly to get my

143.text:
eyes in the right position I have suddenly,
my nose is right up on top of the gun and

149.text:
again the stock length is wrong for me, totally
wrong. All I need to do, and coincidently

153.text:
this gun does actually fit me, put my hand
where it should

155.text:
be, on the middle of the fore end with an
over and an under and if I just mount it there

160.text:
it is virtually in the right sort of place.
The difference is depending where you mount

164.text:
the gun and how you falsify it, you can make
if fit you, unfit you, and do what ever you

170.text:
This is the first time the old English gunmaker
has done this sort of thing and it has attracted

174.text:
guns from near and far. Mark Bladon and his
friend are on familiar territory. They shoot

180.text:
the simulated and the game days offered here
at Hexton. Mark's in the market for a new

187.text:
I have come back today because the offer of
having a gun completely fitted for you and

194.text:
measured seemed too good to be true. So it
was very important to come here and get a

199.text: gun fitted and made to measure.

200.text:
Mathew now takes Mark through the process
of ensuring his William Powell doesn't just

204.text: look beautiful but fits beautifully too.

207.text: Needs to be a little bit lower there.

210.text:
Yup, I can see all of your eye is the honest
truth. I can see all of it and just a bit

215.text:
underneath. So what I will probably do is
just bring the comb down a little bit for

220.text:
you. Now that looks about right to me, perfect.
I can see all of your eye.

223.text:
The stock used for the fittings can be pushed
and pulled in all directions - the size of

228.text:
our chest, face shoulders, all need to be
taken into consideration. So if you have gone

233.text:
up a neck size from 16 to 18 inches your gun
won't fit you quite as well as it once did.

241.text:
These guys cannot stress the importance enough
of a well fitted gun. So why not grab your

246.text:
unloaded shotgun, stick yourself infront of
a mirror and see if you are moulding yourself

250.text: to your gun or whether the gun moulds to you.

255.text:
Right we are going to look at the four movements
in which we can move the gun. We are looking

258.text:
at the length, the bend, the height of the
comb and the cast.

263.text:
First of all we are going to look at the length
of the gun and on the trial gun we can alter

269.text:
this by altering these screws and this. So
what I am going to ask Andrew to do is first

272.text:
of all just mount the gun up into the sky
and we will have a look at the length. Whilst

276.text:
we are looking at Andrew at the moment, he
has got his hand in a reasonable position

280.text:
in the middle of the fore end, but if we come
back round here and we look at his positioning

285.text:
of his back of his hand to his nose we can
probably fit 3 or possibly 4 fingers in. The

291.text:
perfect length we are looking at is to fit
2 fingers in. So if Andrew dismounts the gun

296.text:
now, and what I will do is just undo these
and shorten the stock. So if you just mount

303.text:
the gun up again Andrew and let us just have
a look to see where you are. That looks about

307.text:
right. If we just pop in, so we can see we
have got 2 fingers and if Andrew moves his

311.text:
head forward, a better position of his head
we can see has 2 fingers width between the

316.text: back of his hand and this thing.

321.text:
Next we are going to look at the bend of the
stock. So if Andrew just moves his hand there,

325.text:
we can see the stock is coming down at this
angle and what it creates is different lengths

330.text:
from the trigger pull to what we call the
mid, the toe and the heel of the gun. And

337.text:
this truly goes back to the actual shape of
your shoulder to your breast and as you can

343.text:
see mine is relatively flat, but a larger
person may have one that is more sloping.

348.text:
So what I will do on this is just ask Andrew
to mount it up and see if it fits nicely into

353.text:
this curve of his shoulder. If you just dismount
it a minute Andrew and do that up we can actually

360.text:
see what is going on. So as we can see there,
if I come round and ask Andrew to just let

366.text:
go with his left hand, keep it there, we can
see that the flat of the stock is perfectly

373.text:
in line with his shoulder. If he was a little
bit larger it would be tucked in and have

378.text:
a gap at the top. If he was much smaller the
opposite would happen and we would have a

382.text: gap at the bottom. So we can tell that

384.text:
that is a perfect bend length for Andrew.
Thirdly we will go on to look at the cast.

391.text:
Andrew is a right handed shot as we can see
from the way he is mounting the gun and typically

398.text:
a right handed shot will have cast on or off.
As I know Andrew, he is a right handed shot,

404.text:
shoots with both eyes open and shoots with
a dominant right eye and I roughly know he

410.text:
will roughly be around an 1/8 th cast off
on the gun. So I already know that this gun

417.text:
is cast off to that. And what we can do is
go back to my demonstration earlier of when

423.text:
we are looking the gun is empty, is all we
do is look down the end of the gun and I can

428.text:
see there is a slight curve on the cast of
the gun as I look down it on the left hand

433.text: side and that tells me it is cast off.

436.text:
When we are looking at the height of the comb
what we do is we measure back from the flat

441.text:
of the gun all the way back through to the
back and we have 3 measurements. We measure

446.text:
the height at the comb, height at the face,
which is the mid point and height at the heel.

452.text:
And we measure those because actually the
cast and the bend of the gun will actually

456.text:
change that, but also you need to know how
high up the distance to where the face is

462.text:
to where the eye sits on the barrel. So what
I have asked Andrew to do to do this one,

466.text:
I will ask him, I know the gun is empty, so
I will ask him to shut the gun and just mount

472.text:
the gun at 90 degrees, flat to him, just mount
it flat straight up. What I do then is come

479.text:
round the side and I will just come round
to this side and look down the barrel. Now

484.text:
if you come round to this side you will be
able to see looking straight down the barrel,

489.text:
and if you can hold that there Andrew, if
you look down the barrel you can see all of

493.text:
Andrew's eye and a small piece of his eyelid
at the

498.text:
bottom. His eye then is looking over the top
of the gun and his perception to the end of

503.text:
the gun is coming down onto here and if I
completely raise the gun up like this and

509.text:
Andrew tells me what he can see, what are
you starting to see now?

513.text:
Lots of gun and can you see what the end of
the gun is doing?

515.text:
Not a thing. So what we need to do in that
instance is to look at the height of the comb.

520.text:
So we will go back to the gun and the keys
and what we will do, they are very easy to

529.text:
manipulate these guns. You just slightly undo
the screws and just from my guess work and

536.text:
it really is guess work, trial and error,
getting some feed back from your client exactly

542.text:
where they think it should be and obviously
experience with the shape of people will help.

547.text:
So if you do the same exercise. Again if you
could just mount that gun, perfect, and I

552.text:
will just come round this end, we know it
is empty and come round and look at Andrew.

556.text:
If I look straight down there I can see all
of his eye. There is a possibility that the

562.text:
end of the gun is just covering the bottom
of the coloured piece of his eye. So what

567.text:
I think I will do now is if Andrew drops the
gun down a little bit again, I will just lift

572.text:
it a tiny bit. A tiny measurement will make
a difference obviously when everything goes

577.text:
up to a further distance away, a few millimetres
at

581.text:
this end can make a massive difference on
the bird that is 30 or 40 yards away.

587.text:
See what is going on with that. So if you
just mount that up again Andrew and I will

594.text:
come round again and just have a look and
I can see all of his eye there now. So if

599.text:
I lift his gun up now and I keep raising it
Andrew should now be able to see at the end

604.text:
of the gun all the way up through and even
when he gets to this point where he is going

608.text:
to shoot his very high pheasant he should
still be looking all the way down the end

610.text: of his gun which I hope you are Andrew.

614.text:
So if you bring it back down and mount to
the camera, you will be able to see that you

620.text: can see the full piece of his eye.

626.text:
The fitting has definitely worked for Andrew,
and we hope it has also helped you spot whether

631.text: your gun is a bit rough on the shoulder.

William Powell is keen to do more of these

pop at a few good clays and consider one of

Now if you love shooting you will love the

in this .... beside me. Next it is David on

In all 16 teams helped raise over £20,000

from Judas Priest, Chris de Margary from Simply

697.text:
George Digweed has won yet another European
Title - his second in a month.

702.text:
This time it was the European Fitasc Championships
in Portugal. George dropped just five shots

708.text:
entering a score of 195. Mark Windsor was
second on 193. The competition attracted 800

714.text:
shots from all over the World This is George's
16th European crown.

721.text:
Staying with best British shooting and English
Gunmaker William Powell has announed the arrival

726.text:
of a new over and under model that will go
head to head with the likes of Berreta's highly

730.text:
popular silver pigeon. William powell's perseus
is under £1800.00 and is targeting the entry

736.text:
level shotgun owner who wants something a
little different.

739.text:
You don't want to turn up on a shoot and shoot
the same gun as everybody else really. That

741.text:
is what we are doing with our William Powells
they are different, they are unique and they

746.text: are really good value for money.

748.text:
So will the bad weather be bad news for partridge
shoots this season. Rain during Royal Ascot

754.text:
traditionally means death for partridge chicks.
However the game farmers are reassuring shoots

759.text:
that although the bad weather doesn't make
their job easier, chicks are safe thanks to

767.text:
And finally, Kenya's wildlife crisis has worsened
with 6 of its dwindling lion population being

772.text:
speared to death by angry locals in a single
incident following livestock losses. There

778.text:
are about 1500 lions left in Kenya and they
are being killed at a rate of around 100 a

783.text:
year. Kenya does not allow any hunting. But
so far in 2012 it has had 133 elephant killed

791.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

803.text:
Thank you David. Some really important stories
there, I thought. Now, corvids and what shall

809.text:
we do about them. I know call Simon Barr from
Realtree.

820.text:
If I say it is before dawn on the morning
of the summer solstice you will get an idea

824.text:
of how early it is. I am joining game chef,
Mark Gilchrist, on a crow shooting outing

830.text:
to minimise the impact they are having on
a farmer's crop. We need to be set up in a

836.text:
hide within the next 45 minutes to catch the
crows as they start leaving their roost and

843.text:
You always find big populations of crows where
ever you have got pig farms, chicken farms,

850.text:
or dairy farms. That is where there are big
amounts of crows. Or somewhere where they

855.text:
are fattening bull beef. They are always making
themselves unwelcome customers and when it

858.text:
gets light you will see what I mean. There
are just patches here that they just ruin.

865.text:
When they are doing what they are doing it
doesn't take long to make the crop uneconomical

871.text:
Many will not realise the damage crows cause
to crops. These crafty corvids do not just

877.text:
keep to livestock farms and the young crop
we are trying to protect is sustaining quite

881.text:
a hammering. The birds are not eating the
shoots, but pulling them out of the soil to

886.text:
expose leather jackets, worms and grubs underneath.
We will have a look at this later. But now

892.text:
I want to find out if there is much of an
art to crow decoying as pigeon decoying.

896.text:
Mark what sort of a pattern do you go for
with crows?

899.text:
To make a pattern, it doesn't matter what
it is, the patterns don't make any difference.

904.text:
Anyone telling you want an L shape pattern,
or Z shape pattern, is just making it up.

909.text:
You just want a big area of decoys and a hole
where you want them to land. One tactic that

915.text:
works quite well with crows is a big area
of crows widely dispersed, if you see what

921.text:
I mean. So all the decoys 15 yards apart so
that they come over and look at it and I think.

928.text:
I have got a theory which will probably be
proved wrong at some stage, they don't look

935.text:
at the number of birds they look at the size
that has birds in it. So you are much better

941.text:
off with a sparsely populated area of crows
that is bigger, than more in a smaller area.

951.text: So more on the spread than the density.

953.text:
Yes, if only I was as skilled a journalist
as you are I would be able to use those complicated

959.text:
words that would explain what I was trying
to say.

962.text:
We hear the caws of crows as they make a start
to their day. With the addition of natural

966.text:
foliage covering our Realtree AP cannon netting
we are ready for them. Mark gets a few shots

975.text:
off straight away and opens the batting. Mark
takes the job of controlling vermin on farmland

988.text:
very seriously. I feel quite honoured I may
also get a shot off. As enjoyable as this

993.text:
outing with a gun is, Mark is most definitely
working.

996.text:
So Mark we have caught up with a few now and
it is very different from pigeon shooting.

1001.text:
What would you say are the key differences
when shooting crows over pigeons?

1006.text:
Well, you need to be in the right place at
the right time. This time of year you need

1013.text:
to be up early. Even on a good day it is all
over by 8, 9 o'clock. They find somewhere

1020.text:
else and they spread out. Actually when taking
the shot you need to be a lot stiller. They

1026.text:
are a funny bird in that they are more intelligent,
oddly enough crows can also be quite arrogant

1033.text:
in the sense that once you have got them fooled
you can often think it is incomprehensible

1038.text:
that it can be a trap, if you have got a decent
enough set up they come straight in and they

1044.text:
can be very silly, once you have got them
in that position.

1047.text: Once they have taken the bait they are in.

1049.text:
It may be midsummer but the rain starts coming
down in stair rods. We knew it was forecast,

1056.text:
So Mark we are out on the longest day of the
year, you got me out of bed at 2.30am, it

1064.text:
Keep still, keep still. How on earth did I
miss that.

1072.text:
No, no the first shot. That really was too
pathetic.

1075.text:
I will start again Mark. So it is the longest
day of the year, you got me out of bed very

1080.text:
early. It is tipping down with rain. Talk
to me a little bit about why it is important

1085.text: to come out in these miserable conditions.

1089.text:
You just have to look after the farmer. I
don't have a sporting lease on the 45,000

1093.text:
acres I shoot on. It is all a grace and favour
exercise. So the only thing I can do for the

1099.text:
farmer is be effective or be seen to be making
an effort.

1107.text:
Now it is my turn and with some learning advice
from Mark on steadily swinging through these

1111.text:
deceptively large targets I connect with a
number of satisfying birds.

1118.text: That is it. Lovely. There you go. Lovely shot.

1127.text:
That is it. Lovely. That is it. That is is.
Lovely.

1136.text:
That is another good thing to do. Do exactly
the right thing. Go up on it and if it looks

1140.text:
like it is going to make a better shot, just
don't pull the trigger and then get him.

1144.text:
As the rest of the country starts its day,
less crows come over our hide allowing for

1149.text:
just a few more shots before this crop protection
exercise comes to a halt. We can now pick

1155.text:
up the birds we have shot and have a look
at the damage they have been causing.

1161.text:
Each bird will probably have to pull up, now
let us guess, 10 plants to get a full crop

1167.text:
and there were 100 here the other morning
and ok we may not have killed that many to

1172.text:
take out of the equation, but the rest of
them have heard us banging away and as they

1177.text:
fly over they will remember, because they
are clever birds, they will remember the shooting

1181.text: and won't come any where near it.

1184.text:
Well we have finished up our morning and it
is the summer solstice and we have already

1188.text:
taken huge advantage of the longest day of
the year. We have connected with quite a few

1192.text:
crows and Mark has now packed up the hide
and I think he is getting a little bit excited

1197.text:
because he is .......right I better crack
on.

1203.text:
I have learnt a great deal on this midsummer
management trip from expert Mark. These birds

1209.text:
are far smarter than pigeons and take experience
and commitment to effectively control. Fair

1215.text:
weather shooting this was not, but to do a
good job for the farmer, the smaller bags

1219.text:
are equally as important as the big ones.
Mark has been a great help and I have immensely

1224.text:
enjoyed a fascinating morning with a management
master in his pursuit of excellence. Having

1230.text:
risen at 2.30 and stood in the rain for 5
hours, we both deserve a full English Fieldsports

1235.text: breakfast and a large mug of tea.

1239.text:
Staying with shotguns, how do you clean your
shotgun the best way. Let's ask those clever

1245.text:
As you can see this is an old gun what is
known in the trade as a nail. If you add water

1252.text:
and oxygen to metal it is going to rust. Your
pride and joy will soon end up like this.

1257.text:
Every time you have been shooting, if you
are going to take your gun out on a regular

1261.text:
basis, every week or even every fortnight,
just give your gun a basic clean. Take your

1265.text:
gun apart into 3 main components, fore end,
the barrels, actional stock. Once you have

1274.text:
removed any moisture and surface dirt, spray
the gun with a cleaning oil or fluid. If you

1281.text:
use an oily rag great, but you are putting
oil back on to your gun every time so if you

1285.text:
remove any dirt with clean kitchen roll and
reapply new stuff with new kitchen roll or

1292.text:
something similar, you are not adding dirt
and grit which will scratch the action or

1296.text:
the finish on the woodwork. Spray down the
barrel with your spray or any other spray.

1301.text:
Get a .....brush like so. You can get 2 sized
brushes obviously for different calibres.

1308.text:
You can have a chamber brush and a ball brush.
The chamber

1310.text:
brush is for a slightly larger area where
your shells go. Give it a damn good scrub,

1315.text:
then push it right the way through push through
several times. Once you have done that and

1320.text:
you have loosened any fouling that is in there.
Take a standard piece of kitchen roll, put

1326.text:
it into the top of the barrel like that, simply
brush it through, out it comes the other end.

1334.text:
That is such a tight seal it will have moved
most. Then you will find the bores inside

1341.text:
will be highly polished and cleaned. You can
then reapply a slight amount of oil just to

1348.text:
prevent any moisture getting back into the
barrels and eating away. If you look after

1352.text: them, guns will last you a lifetime.

1360.text:
Now we filmed that for Browning at the Oxford
Gun Company shop and clay ground, and the

1364.text:
owners of the Oxford Gun Company this year
celebrate 30 years in the business. So they

1368.text:
are throwing a party for the great, the good,
the bad and even the ugly from the shooting

1373.text:
Made me feel so welcome since taking on the
Game Fair. Thank you very much.

1385.text:
This week we are celebrating Euro2012 and

some foreign films. Thanks to everyone who

1406.text:
you Turkish is a bad language - you will find
this fascinating, not least that they are

1411.text:
out with a group called Yoncali Timi Nazim
Öksü, which means literally 'Orphans Master

at work - good grief, can't we have a dog

1473.text:
So we have to introduce you to this channel.
Called DylanDog69 it's in Italian and is all

1478.text:
about, well, not just catching enormous catfish

afterwards, splashing around and it's hard

1488.text:
Back to Blighty and airgunning: CountryPursuitsTV
has a Daystate Mk4IS on test. Rabbits be nervous.

1495.text:
He tries it out next to a tuned Air Arms Evo2
and finds it is almost but not quite the Evo

1500.text:
Knevo's equal. Good work by CountryPursuitsTV.
Bad luck those rabbits.

1505.text:
If you ever wondered whether it could be done,
BigSigh66 shows that it can, with the correct

1509.text:
windage, elevation adjustments and surely
a modicum of luck: a .204 Ruger shooting a

1515.text:
39-grain Sierra Blitzking with a muzzle velocity
of 3,700 feet per second kills a rabbit at

1520.text:
458 yards - that's more than a quarter of
a mile. Believe it, or not.

1526.text:
Let's finish on a film so painfully patronising
and pointless, so moronic, so everything that's

1531.text:
wrong with both football and ordinary telly.
It comes from some sleeping beauty of a BBC

1536.text:
producer who thinks it would be an awesome
idea for the footballer Ian Wright to go hunting

1542.text:
There must be a simpler way, Jesus, that is
terrible that is.

1546.text:
Go to the butcher and buy it. Somebody else
killed it then.

1552.text:
BBCWorldwide has the gall to say the former
Arsenal striker is 'surprisingly squeamish'

1556.text:
when it cannot bring itself to show any of
the hunting that takes place, only Wright

1560.text:
blithering in the noonday sun while men who
live and die by what they catch and hunt are

1564.text:
reduced to being victims of his otiose attempts
at humour. It's the new Reithian principles:

1569.text:
misinform, ill-educate and you will never
be fired for hiring a footballer. It is television

1574.text:
as voluntary tinnitus. Thank you for listening.
Rant over.

1577.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1581.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1589.text:
Well that is it for this week. We are of course
back next week. And if you are watching this

1593.text:
on YouTube you will see various things appearing
beside me. You can click them and subscribe

1598.text:
to our channel or subscribe to this show Fieldsports
Britain by going to our special shows page

1603.text:
www.youtube.com/shows/fieldsportsbritain or
you can go to our website www.fieldsportschannel.tv

1612.text:
where you can click to like us on Facebook,
or follow us on Twitter, or scroll down to

1616.text:
the bottom of the page where there is a box.
Pop your email address into that and we will

1620.text:
contact you remorselessly for ever. This has
been Fieldsports Britain going bang and loving
